f2b1a038b369fa421c93e4b6bd034704 (02:24): so I am using a php script and it creates a SQL insert string that says
7daec93ba796fa047a85c16980a877d8 (02:25): Wolfpaws: so basically I don't have to explicitly state that is throws an exception?
f2b1a038b369fa421c93e4b6bd034704 (02:25): now when  go into the mySQL database the second field the 4396 field is 127
f2b1a038b369fa421c93e4b6bd034704 (02:25): whenever I run this using the script it enters 127
f2b1a038b369fa421c93e4b6bd034704 (02:26): now if I just hard code that second field, it then works fine
d71787cd3c4816fecd6399c982a73d16 (02:26): RootSnatch, this isnt a PHP problem, its an SQL problem... but...
d71787cd3c4816fecd6399c982a73d16 (02:26): the problem is most likely the integer size you selected
f2b1a038b369fa421c93e4b6bd034704 (02:26): but when I hardcode the value it works fine
f2b1a038b369fa421c93e4b6bd034704 (02:26): what I stupid thing of me
d71787cd3c4816fecd6399c982a73d16 (02:27): RootSnatch, i'm not sure, but tinyint might be 8 bits only
f2b1a038b369fa421c93e4b6bd034704 (02:27): it is a tinyint(20) how high a number does that allow for
d71787cd3c4816fecd6399c982a73d16 (02:27): max of 127 is right for 8-bit signed
d71787cd3c4816fecd6399c982a73d16 (02:27): try using SMALLINT or just INT
d71787cd3c4816fecd6399c982a73d16 (02:28): otherwise... maybe your code isnt doing what you think it is, if you think it should be entering one number and it is entering another one
